item.title: Upcoming news
Ancient gold ingots stolen from Syria's National Museum in Damascus
item.description: Several ancient gold ingots were stolen from Syria's National Museum in Damascus, according to sources close to the institution's management and security officials. The robbery occurred overnight between Sunday and Monday, with six items taken from the museum's classical wing, which houses artefacts from the Hellenistic, Roman, and Byzantine periods. The stolen items were described as gold ingots, though their exact age and origin have not been specified. The museum, which remained untouched during Syria's civil war, is now closed for security reasons and is expected to reopen next week. Syrian authorities have not officially confirmed the burglary, but several employees and guards were detained and interrogated following the incident. Security forces have since restricted access to the exhibition halls, and no outward signs of the theft were visible when journalists visited the museum. The incident highlights ongoing concerns about the protection of cultural heritage in post-conflict

item.title: China Blames US for $13 Billion Bitcoin Heist in 2020
item.description: China’s cybersecurity agency has accused the U.S. government of orchestrating the theft of approximately $13 billion worth of Bitcoin, linking the crime to a state-sponsored hacking operation. The heist, which occurred in December 2020, involved the theft of 127,272 Bitcoin from the LuBian mining pool, once one of the world’s largest Bitcoin mining operations. China claims that the movement of the stolen cryptocurrency, which was later linked to funds seized by U.S. authorities, suggests the involvement of a government-level hacking operation. The U.S. government recently confiscated the stolen Bitcoin as part of an investigation into money laundering involving Chen Zhi, a Cambodian businessman linked to the Prince Group. U.S. authorities allege that the stolen funds were used to fund illegal crypto mining operations. The Chinese government has become more vocal about accusing the U.S. of cyberattacks in recent months, citing other incidents including alleged attacks on Chinese compani

item.title: Trump's White House Renovations: A Mar-a-Lago-Inspired Makeover
item.description: Former President Donald Trump is making significant changes to the White House, with many elements inspired by his luxurious Mar-a-Lago estate in Palm Beach. The Oval Office has been revamped with gold fixtures, including a gilded presidential seal and ivy motifs replaced with golden accents. Trump also transformed the Rose Garden, replacing it with a paved courtyard that echoes the outdoor spaces at Mar-a-Lago. Outside the White House, two 88-foot flagpoles were installed, similar to the ones at Mar-a-Lago. The most controversial modification, however, is the demolition of the historic East Wing to make way for a grand ballroom, which will rival Mar-a-Lago's ballroom in size and opulence. This ballroom, funded by major corporate donors like Google, Amazon, and Microsoft, is expected to cost around $300 million. The alterations have sparked criticism from historians and the public, who are concerned about the historical preservation of the White House and the lack of oversight on the r

item.title: Jonathan Braun, granted clemency by Trump, sentenced to 27 months after new criminal charges
item.description: Jonathan Braun, a convicted drug dealer who had his sentence commuted by former President Donald Trump in January 2021, has been sentenced to 27 months in prison after violating the terms of his supervised release. Braun, 42, was accused of multiple serious offenses, including sexually assaulting his children's nanny and physically abusing a 3-year-old child. His original drug trafficking sentence was commuted by Trump during his final hours in office. Braun's release was reportedly influenced by his family's connections to Jared Kushner, Trump's son-in-law. However, after his release, Braun's behavior escalated, leading to criminal charges. He was also accused of assaulting a nurse with a hospital IV pole and threatening a fellow congregant at a New York synagogue. Braun was detained in April 2025 after being accused of assaulting the toddler. Despite having a record as a high-ranking member of a drug smuggling operation, Braun's release was initially seen as a chance for rehabilitati

item.title: Trump Denies Using Home Depot Decor for Oval Office Gold Accents
item.description: President Donald Trump recently defended the opulent gold accents in the Oval Office, which have been a topic of public discussion since he took office. In April, the Wall Street Journal reported that Trump enlisted a 'gold guy' to add custom gilded finishes, including carvings for the fireplace mantel and ornate molding. However, these golden designs closely resemble plastic polyurethane appliques made by Ekena Millwork, which are sold at Home Depot for around $58.07. During a Fox News interview with Laura Ingraham, Trump was asked whether these golden motifs came from the hardware store, to which he firmly responded, 'No, this is not Home Depot stuff. This is not Home Depot.' The video, posted by Ingraham, was captioned claiming the gold accents were authentic. BuzzFeed had previously reached out to Ekena Millwork, the company that manufactures the decorative pieces, and they confirmed that they work with several design firms in Washington, D.C., and believe that the Oval Office's fi

item.title: Challenges Facing Spain's Railway Infrastructure Management and the Role of Adif
item.description: The article discusses the complexities and issues surrounding the management of railway infrastructure in Spain, focusing on Adif (Administrador de Infraestructuras Ferroviarias), the body responsible for maintaining and overseeing the country's rail networks. The piece touches on historical perspectives, from the privatization of railways in the UK to Spain's own experiences with railway management. The author highlights the financial challenges faced by Adif, including a massive debt burden and the tension between high-speed rail and conventional networks. The article critiques the impact of privatization and the competition in high-speed rail services, noting that three companies currently operate in Spain, but all are struggling financially. Moreover, it examines the ongoing issue of railway gauge compatibility, a lingering problem since the adoption of the Iberian gauge. The author refers to a historical report and quotes from industry figures to underscore the challenges of maint

item.title: US-Israel Agreement Allows Continued Israeli Attacks on Lebanon Despite Peace Talks
item.description: Former Israeli ambassador to Washington, Michael Herzog, revealed that the Israeli government had informal agreements with Washington to continue bombing targets in Lebanon, despite a ceasefire negotiated by the US and France in late 2019. This deal allows Israel to maintain 'freedom of action' against threats when other parties are unwilling or unable to contain them. Herzog's statement sheds light on why the US has been largely silent regarding Israeli airstrikes and commando raids on Lebanese sites suspected of being linked to Hezbollah. These attacks, which have resulted in the deaths of at least 100 Lebanese civilians, contradict the 'final cessation of hostilities' that President Biden promised after the ceasefire. While reports about a memorandum of understanding allowing Israel to defend itself in Lebanon have circulated, Herzog's comments confirm this secret arrangement and clarify that Israel considers it a carte blanche to continue its military actions. item.title: Over 100 Hamas militants trapped in Gaza tunnel amid political maneuvering and potential exile routes
item.description: European and American observers report that between 100 and 200 Hamas fighters are trapped in a southern Gaza tunnel. Israeli General Eyal Zamir has offered them a stark choice: surrender or be eliminated. The incident has moved beyond a purely military issue and entered the political arena, with former President Trump sending aides to broker a deal during talks with Prime Minister Netanyahu. There is concern in the United States that the removal of these militants could jeopardize a recent ceasefire and hinder discussions about deploying an international force in Gaza. A Hamas Izz al-Din al-Qassam Brigades leader dismissed any commitment, stating that surrender is not an option for them. Netanyahu’s isolation is increasing his dependence on the United States, which supports him internationally. item.title: John Cleese Cancels Israel Performances Amid Controversy Over BDS Movement
item.description: British comedian and actor John Cleese has canceled his upcoming performances in Israel, which had sold out, after reposting anti-Israel content on social media. The shows, scheduled between November 26 and December 1 in Jerusalem and Tel Aviv, were being organized by Alon Yurik Productions. In a statement, the producers expressed regret over the cancellation, claiming that Cleese had succumbed to pressure from the BDS (Boycott, Divestment, Sanctions) movement. The statement also highlighted that all tickets had already been sold. Cleese had previously postponed his shows from June to November due to the ongoing war with Iran. However, his recent social media activity, including reposting videos critical of Israel and its leadership, raised concerns. Among the posts were a video of actor Mandy Patinkin criticizing Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and another featuring actor Mark Ruffalo criticizing his Jewish friends. Despite the controversy, Cleese has not publicly commented on the c

item.title: NSO appoints Trump ally to lead spyware company amid ongoing surveillance controversy
item.description: NSO Group has appointed David Friedman, a former Trump official and U.S. ambassador to Israel, as executive chairman to steer the notorious Israeli spyware company back toward profitability. The firm, best known for Pegasus, has faced a decade of allegations of misuse by governments to spy on journalists, human rights activists, and dissidents. Amnesty International reported Pegasus targeting staff and civil society members in the West Bank in 2018, and later investigations connected Pegasus to surveillance of Jamal Khashoggi’s wife in 2018. In 2025, Amnesty highlighted Pegasus-targeted journalists from a Serbian network. The Biden administration previously blacklisted NSO for supplying spyware to foreign governments, and a 2024 federal ruling found NSO liable for reverse engineering Meta’s WhatsApp to compromise thousands of individuals. A U.S. judge recently allowed WhatsApp to block NSO’s products, a decision NSO is appealing. Despite these legal and ethical challenges, NSO aims to

item.title: Germany Considers Raising Retirement Age to Address Workforce Shortages and Funding for Rearmament
item.description: Germany is facing a significant demographic challenge, with a growing shortage of workers due to an aging population and low birth rates. In the first quarter of 2025, the country reached a record 1.74 million vacant job positions, the highest number since reunification. The aging population exacerbates the issue, with the elderly making up a larger portion of the population than young people. To address these problems, the government is considering raising the retirement age to 70, as the current gradual increase to 67 is seen as insufficient. The pension system in Germany relies on workers' contributions, but the decreasing workforce threatens its sustainability. Experts argue that immigration is essential to fill labor gaps, and efforts are underway to improve migrant qualification recognition and expand opportunities for vulnerable groups in the workforce. There are also discussions around increasing work hours, but there is skepticism regarding the feasibility and health impact of

item.title: The Decline of the European Union: A Reality Check
item.description: The European Union has faced multiple crises in recent years, and a recent editorial in the *Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung* by Nikolas Busse outlines its failures. From the collapse of the EU’s foreign policy ambitions, such as its inability to defend itself against threats and to maintain a role in global politics, to internal issues like the failure of the Stability and Growth Pact and the inability to form a unified asylum policy, the EU's foundations are crumbling. The article argues that European countries are increasingly turning to nationalism as a response to the EU's shortcomings, with countries like Germany emphasizing economic and military strength at the national level over European unity. Busse suggests that the solution is not to reinforce the EU, but to focus on strengthening individual states, pointing to a shift away from the EU's ideal of unity and toward national sovereignty. This commentary reflects broader concerns that the EU’s integration model is no longer viab

item.title: Former Intel Engineer Allegedly Steals 18,000 Confidential Files Amid Layoffs
item.description: In a dramatic turn of events following Intel's ongoing downsizing, a former software engineer, Jinfeng Luo, is accused of stealing around 18,000 sensitive files from the company. Luo, who had been employed at Intel since 2014, was laid off in July 2024 as part of a wave of job cuts within the company. Prior to his departure, Luo allegedly transferred a large volume of confidential data from his work laptop to an external device, which raised alarms within Intel's cybersecurity team. Despite initial failed attempts, he succeeded in copying the files to a personal network-attached storage device just days before his termination. Despite multiple attempts to contact Luo, including phone calls, emails, and physical letters, Intel has been unable to reach him. The company has filed a lawsuit seeking $250,000 in damages and the return of the stolen data. This case is not the first instance of data theft at Intel; another former engineer was caught taking confidential files to secure a job at

item.title: Trump-branded Wines Sold at Military Stores, Raising Ethical Concerns
item.description: Wines and ciders from Donald Trump’s personal brand are now available at military-run stores, including those operated by the U.S. Coast Guard, where military personnel and their families can purchase tax-free goods. This move has sparked controversy, as critics point out the potential ethical issues surrounding the sale of Trump-branded products at government facilities. While it may not directly violate legal restrictions, such as the Emoluments Clause, the sale raises questions about the optics of profiting from the presidency. Trump’s businesses, including those operating during his presidency, have faced scrutiny for potential conflicts of interest, especially in light of his extensive brand presence in both domestic and international markets. During his time in office, Trump’s properties were often used by foreign officials, further heightening concerns of inappropriate financial gain. While Trump no longer personally manages the Trump Organization, he still owns it, which makes

item.title: Starship could cut Uranus travel time to about 6.5 years with in-orbit refueling and aerocapture
item.description: A recent MIT study suggests that SpaceX’s Starship, if used for a Uranus mission, could drastically shorten travel time from roughly 13–14 years to about 6.5 years by leveraging in-orbit refueling and potentially aerocapture at Uranus. The analysis compares a 5-ton UOP-like probe needing multiple propellant transfers to reach Uranus, with alternative mission concepts that could boost payload to 25 tons. Aerocapture offers the biggest potential reduction in transit time, but it introduces serious engineering challenges, such as thermal protection on a vehicle exposed to space for seven years and maintaining cryogenic propellants without reliable long-term storage. Without aerocapture, even the Starship’s capabilities leave arrival velocities and propellant needs constrained, potentially requiring nine tanker flights. The study notes that current NASA plans would not launch before 2035, and a venturing into outer solar system exploration hinges on Starship meeting final specifications, p

item.title: Chris Hedges Critiques Donald Trump as a Modern-Day Dictator
item.description: In his article, Chris Hedges draws a stark comparison between Donald Trump and Latin American dictators, arguing that Trump embodies the same authoritarian tendencies seen in past despots who were backed by oligarchs and imperialists. Hedges compares Trump to notorious figures such as Rafael Trujillo, Anastasio Somoza, and François Duvalier, noting their shared characteristics: corruption, violence, and a thirst for self-glorification. He highlights how Trump’s administration reflects the same tactics employed by these dictators to maintain power—manipulating elections, silencing opposition, and spreading dangerous ideologies. Hedges critiques Trump’s policies and behaviors, from his disregard for scientific facts to his alliances with controversial figures like Jeffrey Epstein. He warns that Trump’s leadership has created a world where reality is distorted, and any dissent is labeled as treason. Through his actions and rhetoric, Trump has transformed the political landscape into a gro

item.title: Analysis of disparate sentencing in a homeless man versus a white-collar fraud case
item.description: This Snopes fact-check revisits a 2011 comparison of two criminal cases involving similar ages and life pressures but vastly different crimes and outcomes. Roy Brown, a 54-year-old homeless man in Shreveport, Louisiana, robbed a Capital One bank of a single $100 bill, surrendered the next day, and received a 15-year sentence for first-degree robbery. Paul R. Allen, 55, a former CEO of Taylor Bean & Whitaker, was convicted in a multibillion-dollar mortgage fraud scheme connected to the collapse of TBW and related banks. Allen received a 40-month prison term after cooperating with investigators and accounting for mitigating factors, despite the broader financial damage attributed to his role in the scheme. Snopes documents the contrast by citing court records and news coverage, noting limited corroboration for Brown’s case beyond the available sentencing records. The piece emphasizes the complexity of criminal justice outcomes, including considerations of intent, non-violence, cooperatio

item.title: Corporate Exploitation and Innovation in Waste Recycling Technologies
item.description: The article explores how multinational corporations and global organizations are turning human excrement and wastewater into valuable resources. Organizations like the Toilet Board Coalition, formed by companies such as Unilever and Firmenich, are collaborating with UN agencies to advance the circular economy by promoting new sanitation and waste-to-value technologies. The article discusses projects that use human waste to produce hydrogen, electricity, fertilizer, mineral resources, food, and even potable water. India's massive campaign to end open defecation is highlighted, as it aims to capture biological resources for industrial use. Using the black soldier fly larvae, waste is converted into proteins, lipids, and food ingredients, now legal for human consumption in the EU and other regions. item.title: Belgian Defense Minister's Controversial Threat to Moscow Amid Rising Tensions
item.description: The Belgian Defense Minister, Theo Francken, recently sparked outrage by threatening to 'erase Moscow from the map.' Francken, known for his controversial stances, had previously defended Israel's actions in Gaza, and now he has escalated tensions with his remarks about Russia. This is not the first time European leaders have made such inflammatory statements; earlier in the war, French Economy Minister Bruno Le Maire predicted European sanctions would devastate Russia’s economy. However, these bold predictions have not materialized as expected. Instead, Russia’s military production has grown, and reports suggest that the country has found unconventional ways to source materials for its military, including extracting semiconductors from discarded household appliances. The Belgian minister's provocative comments come as NATO and Russia continue their standoff, with growing concerns about the global escalation of the war. Francken's words have already drawn responses from Russian officia

item.title: DOJ faces staffing crisis as loyalty screening discourages applicants
item.description: The Justice Department is experiencing a severe staffing challenge as a large number of vacancies remain unfilled and the agency confronts a mounting backlog of cases. Reportedly, prospective hires are subjected to a loyalty assessment that requires them to express enthusiasm for President Trump’s executive orders or policies and explain how they would advance them. Critics describe this vetting as politically charged and misaligned with the nonpolitical nature of federal careers, calling it a workaround for partisan alignment. Notably, several DOJ divisions, including the Civil Rights Division, have seen high turnover, with many career attorneys leaving and only a few replacements. Additional reports indicate that hundreds of DOJ employees associated with cases seen as anti-Trump under the Biden administration have been removed, with successors aligned to the current administration. The Post and Reuters cite ongoing staff departures in key legal offices, and some hires are now sourced

item.title: How the CIA Managed Intelligence Before the Outbreak of the Ukraine War
item.description:
In 2021, Bill Burns became director of the CIA and immediately reinstated 'Casa Rusia,' the agency's unit focused on monitoring Russia, signifying a strategic return to Cold War-era intelligence activities. According to journalist Tim Weiner, author of 'The Mission,' the CIA had been anticipating military escalation since at least 2014, closely observing Russian military buildups and coded communications near the Ukrainian border. Rather than keeping these observations secret, the CIA and NSA opted for high-profile information disclosures between late 2021 and early 2022, aiming to deter Russian action and shape media narratives—what was referred to as 'preventive intelligence.' For the first time, intelligence reports typically reserved for the president were widely shared with the press and allies, showcasing details about troop movements and possible Russian operations.

item.title: U.S. B-52 Bombers Arrive in Spain Amid Rising Tensions with Russia
item.description: On November 7, 2025, U.S. B-52 bombers, capable of carrying nuclear weapons, landed at the NATO air base in Morón de la Frontera, Spain. The deployment comes at a time of heightened tensions between Washington and Moscow, with fears of a renewed arms race. These bombers, coming from Barksdale Air Force Base in Louisiana, are part of NATO's efforts to increase its influence near Russia's borders. The Pentagon has euphemistically described the mission as part of the 'Bomber Task Force Europe 26-1', a display of military might meant to reinforce deterrence on Europe's eastern flank. This comes shortly after Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov confirmed that Moscow is preparing nuclear tests in response to U.S. directives. The increasing military posturing follows remarks from U.S. President Donald Trump, who instructed the Department of Defense to resume nuclear testing, accusing Russia and China of conducting underground tests. item.title: BBC Newsroom Resignations Follow Controversy Over Trump Speech Edits; Typhoon Kalmaegi Hits Philippines
item.description: The article compiles global news highlights across multiple regions, focusing on political and international matters. It reports on BBC executives resigning after criticism of how a Trump speech was edited for broadcast, with the BBC noting that Trump has threatened to sue over the edited speech. The roundup also notes ongoing coverage of international conflicts, including the Israel-Hamas war and the Russia-Ukraine war. In addition, natural disaster news is featured, including a new typhoon striking the Philippines in the wake of Typhoon Kalmaegi. The piece situates these developments within the broader context of headlines across U.S. politics, global markets, and major international events. The overall narrative emphasizes leadership changes in media, potential legal action connected to speech editing, geopolitical tensions, and climate-related disasters affecting millions.

item.title: Drone Attack Targets Russian Commercial Mission in Stockholm Amid Rising Tensions
item.description: On the night of November 8th, 2025, a drone once again targeted the Russian commercial mission building in Stockholm, throwing paint over it. This incident is part of a growing trend of similar attacks on Russian diplomatic missions in Sweden, with more than 20 such attacks recorded since May of the previous year. The attacks typically involve drones dropping paint, often in glass containers, which poses a danger of injuries from shards or splashes. The Russian government has repeatedly condemned these actions, stressing that they violate the Vienna Convention of 1961, which obliges host nations to ensure the safety of foreign diplomatic missions. Despite these protests, Swedish authorities have failed to identify or prosecute any suspects, with investigations yielding no results. Russian officials argue that Sweden's inaction reflects a deliberate political stance and a violation of international agreements, as these attacks endanger both diplomatic staff and civilians living near the

item.title: Coal Miners in West Virginia Struggle with Black Lung as Disease Rates Rise
item.description: In the coal mining heartland of West Virginia, a growing number of miners, including those in their 30s and 40s, are battling black lung disease, a condition once associated with older workers. Lisa Emery, a respiratory therapist and director of the New River Health Association Black Lung Clinic, witnesses firsthand the increasing severity of the disease among miners, some of whom require double lung transplants by their mid-40s. As miners are forced to dig through more rock to access coal, they are being exposed to dangerous levels of respirable crystalline silica dust, which is causing rapid deterioration in their health. Despite efforts to protect miners through regulations by the U.S. Mine Safety and Health Administration, the risks remain high. Emery is deeply emotional about the plight of these miners and believes that she was put on earth to help them. The story sheds light on the human cost of coal mining, the increasing rates of black lung disease, and the struggles of a commu

item.title: Albania's EU bid amid deepening narcotics-linked corruption and state infiltration
item.description: The article examines Albania under Prime Minister Edi Rama, portraying a tight intertwining of politics, corruption, and organized crime. It highlights Rama’s government as pursuing European Union accession while facing accusations of widespread corruption and criminal infiltration within state institutions. The piece traces the career of ex-vice prime minister Arben Ahmetaj, his 2022 expulsion from the party, and his subsequent exile after facing corruption allegations linked to a controversial waste-to-energy project in Elbasan. It discusses how incinerators funded by public money became focal points for alleged graft, with two of three planned facilities completed and one abandoned after significant costs. The piece also covers broader criminal activity by Albanian networks, including cannabis production, drug trafficking, and money laundering, noting Europol and Italian authorities’ warnings about criminal groups with ties to government circles. It mentions the alleged connections

item.title: Russian Forces Advance Toward Pokrovsk Amid Extended Urban Combat
item.description: Russian forces are reportedly nearing the city of Pokrovsk in Ukraine's Donetsk region, with intensified urban fighting as surrounding troops have effectively besieged the city. A battalion commander cited by CNN described the situation as difficult, with firefights in urban areas and shelling from various weapons, while a Ukrainian drone unit member noted that Russian movement is so rapid that drone operators struggle to keep pace. The delay in Ukrainian command decisions is suggested to risk higher casualties, echoing past experiences in Batmut (2023) and Avdiivka (2024). Pokrovsk’s strategic importance lay in its road and rail connections to Donetsk, Kostyantynivka, Dnipro, and Zaporizhzhia, serving as a logistics hub for Ukrainian operations and supporting smaller settlements around the area. Since the summer, Russian siege efforts and drone/artillery strikes have pressured Kyiv to reroute supply lines, diminishing Pokrovsk’s logistical role and marking a tactical gain for Russia.

item.title: Trump faces voter appeal on live TV as he touts affordability amid inflation concerns
item.description: The article reports on a Fox News appearance by President Donald Trump, where he responded to Regina Foley, a three-time Trump voter who urged rapid cost-of-living relief. Foley’s on-air message emphasized struggles on groceries and utilities and warned Republicans about losing Congress in 2026. Trump replied by highlighting declining prices in energy and overall affordability, framing himself as sympathetic to Foley and insisting that prices would continue to fall as energy costs drop. The piece juxtaposes Trump’s claims with statistical context: gasoline averages around $3.12 per gallon (down 8% from 2024), electricity prices rising in multiple states, and grocery prices up year over year. It also cites polls showing disapproval of Trump for inflation and mixed assessments of affordability among the public. The article concludes by noting opinion polls and political implications, including Republicans’ concerns about grocery costs and ongoing national debates over inflation.

item.title: Trump grants pardons to allies connected to efforts to overturn 2020 election
item.description: President Donald Trump issued a broad set of pardons to a number of political allies who were connected to efforts to challenge the results of the 2020 presidential election. The pardon proclamation, publicly shared by Ed Martin, the Pardon Attorney, on social media, lists prominent figures including Rudy Giuliani, Sidney Powell, and former White House Chief of Staff Mark Meadows, among many others. The document describes the pardons as a “full, complete, and unconditional pardon” and states that they apply to federal offenses, not to state or local charges. The proclamation asserts that the pardons rectify a national injustice and contribute to national reconciliation. Some recipients were co-defendants implicated in legal actions in Georgia related to attempts to undermine Trump’s 2020 loss. The White House and Martin’s office have been contacted for additional information. In a related move, Trump granted clemency to a retired New York City police officer convicted in 2023 of stalki

item.title: Experts and Critics Slam Trump's Proposal for 50-Year Mortgages
item.description: Donald Trump's proposal for a 50-year mortgage plan has sparked significant backlash from experts, analysts, and social media users alike. The former president recently hinted at the plan, which administration officials later confirmed. Critics argue that such a proposal would significantly increase the total cost of a home, trapping buyers in debt for much of their lives. For example, a $400,000 house on a 30-year mortgage at 6% interest would cost the buyer around $863,000, but under Trump's 50-year plan, that cost would rise to $1.38 million—half a million more in interest. The idea was labeled a 'spectacularly dumb' move by many, with political figures and commentators pointing out that it would benefit banks while worsening the financial burden on Americans. Others expressed frustration over Trump's perceived lack of understanding regarding housing affordability, and some critics even stated they regretted voting for him, citing the proposal as a prime example of his detachment fr

item.title: Alleged Torture and Abuse of Palestinians in Israeli Detention Centers
item.description: The Israeli military prosecutor, Yifat Tomer-Yerushalmi, was arrested and removed from her position after leaking a video exposing the torture of Palestinian prisoners at the Sde Teiman concentration camp. This military base in the Negev Desert, close to Gaza, was converted into a detention and torture center after the passage of the 2023 Illegal Fighters Law. Detainees, often arrested arbitrarily, are subjected to severe physical and psychological abuse. Human rights organizations like B'Tselem have highlighted various forms of torture used against Palestinian prisoners, including sexual violence, physical assault, and deprivation of basic needs such as medical care and proper hygiene. The torture practices at Sde Teiman have been compared to those at Guantanamo Bay and Abu Ghraib. Additionally, Palestinian medical personnel have been detained and abused under similar conditions. These acts are considered violations of international law, including the Geneva Conventions, and have led

item.title: ODF 1.4 Launch Celebrates Two Decades of OpenDocument Standard Enhancements
item.description: ODF 1.4 marks a milestone in the OpenDocument Format’s history, celebrating its 20th anniversary under the OASIS Open umbrella. The release introduces several interoperability and accessibility improvements, with contributions from major players such as Collabora, The Document Foundation, IBM, Nokia, KDE, and LibreOffice community members. Key upgrades include the ability to place tables inside shapes, bridging gaps with other formats like Microsoft OOXML, and enhancing cross-format workflows. Accessibility receives a boost through decorative object marking, allowing screen readers to skip decorative images and shapes to reduce clutter for assistive technologies. The update also adds an overlap prevention property to better manage layout, enabling anchored objects to avoid overlapping other elements. Text direction support has been expanded to accommodate a 90-degree counter-clockwise rotation, enabling content to flow from left-to-right and then top-to-bottom in this rotated orientati

item.title: Biden's Mental Decline and the Controversy Surrounding His Presidency
item.description: The article discusses the controversial allegations surrounding U.S. President Joe Biden's mental health and the use of an 'autopen' device to sign official documents. The device mimics Biden's signature and has allegedly been used for pardons, appointments, and executive orders. The article claims that Biden’s cognitive decline was evident, and his administration allegedly covered it up. It highlights a congressional investigation that questions Biden's ability to govern and the legality of decisions made under his name. Testimonies, including from his former chief of staff, Ron Klain, suggest Biden struggled with basic tasks, including debate preparations. The report calls for further scrutiny of Biden's health and the actions of his closest aides. The situation raises concerns about constitutional issues, especially regarding pardons and executive orders signed with the autopen. Critics, including former President Trump, have raised questions about the legitimacy of Biden's actions

item.title: Sentinel-1D Deployment: ESA Boosts Ariane 6 Cadence with Fourth Flight
item.description: The article reports on Europe's November 4, 2025 launch of the Sentinel-1D satellite aboard Ariane 62 flight VA265 from the Guiana Space Centre, marking the fourth mission of the Ariane 6 family and the completion of the initial Sentinel-1 constellation. Sentinel-1D, a C-band SAR Earth observation satellite built by Thales Alenia Space for the European Space Agency on the PRIMA platform, weighs 2184 kg and features a 12.3-meter deployable SAR antenna capable of up to 5-meter resolution. The satellite includes five panels and 280 transmitter/receiver modules, with an instrument AIS for maritime traffic monitoring. Its mission life is estimated at 7.5 years, with propellant capacity for 12 years, and it uses 14 propulsion motors. The article explains how Sentinel-1D will operate in the same orbital plane as Sentinel-1C to maximize revisit times, and contrasts prior Sentinel-1A/B lifecycles, noting the prolonged gaps caused by satellite outages and launch vehicle issues. item.description: The Houthis announced the dismantling of a covert espionage network coordinated from a joint operations room based in Saudi Arabia. item.description: The article chronicles the rise of the Berlin Wall on August 13, 1961, detailing how the East German regime quickly fortified the border with barricades and barbed wire while workers and soldiers controlled crossings. It highlights Conrad Schumann as the first known escapee and emphasizes that, over 28 years, many attempted to flee to the West using diverse methods. A significant focus is placed on underground tunnels as one of the most romantic and successful escape routes. Early tunnels emerged within weeks, such as one dug from West Berlin into the Pankow cemetery to rescue girlfriends, followed by others like the Niebank couple who leveraged a visa system to plan a move to the West. The narrative covers multiple tunnels built by locals, including the famous Tunnel 29, constructed by students and Italian collaborators, which enabled 130+ people to reach the West. item.description: Luke Humphries achieved a stunning nine-dart finish in his 5-3 victory over Michael Smith at the Grand Slam of Darts in Wolverhampton. Despite early struggles with his doubles, Humphries found his form with a 139 checkout, and then capped off his performance with a perfect leg at 4-3 to seal his second televised nine-darter. The English world number one described the match as one of the strangest games he had ever been involved in, adding that the victory was a testament to the unpredictable nature of darts. Humphries, who needs three legs from his final group match to progress, remarked on the unexpected nature of the game and his surprise at hitting the nine-darter. item.description: The Canadian Premier League final between Atletico Ottawa and Cavalry FC will be remembered for the incredible conditions and a stunning piece of football magic. The match, held in Ottawa, was played amidst a fierce blizzard with temperatures dropping to -8°C. The snowstorm caused repeated delays, with players clearing the pitch, goalkeepers using shovels, and a snowplough making an appearance before extra time. Despite the extreme weather, Atletico Ottawa clinched their inaugural North Star Cup with a 2-1 extra-time victory. The match saw Fraser Aird give Cavalry the lead with a 33rd-minute penalty, celebrated by a snow-slide before being pelted with snowballs by the home fans. However, David Rodriguez of Atletico Ottawa would steal the show, scoring a bicycle kick that deflected off the bar to level the match, followed by a chip over Cavalry's goalkeeper Marco Carducci in extra time to secure the win. item.title: Post Office extends deal with Fujitsu as it plans to transition to new software system
item.description: The Post Office has agreed to extend its controversial contract with Fujitsu, agreeing to pay an additional £41 million for the use of the Horizon software system until March 2027. This decision is part of the company's ongoing plan to move away from Fujitsu as it seeks a new supplier. The Horizon software has been at the heart of a major scandal, with hundreds of sub-postmasters wrongfully convicted of fraud and theft due to errors in the system. Despite Fujitsu executives acknowledging a 'moral obligation' to contribute financially to the victims of the scandal, the company has yet to settle on a final amount. The Post Office is committed to moving to a new system and has set a timeline to award a contract for a new supplier by July 2026. The scandal, which has been described as the UK's largest miscarriage of justice, continues to have legal and financial repercussions. item.title: US Senate Advances Deal to End Government Shutdown, Funding Extended Until January 30
item.description: The US Senate has reached a deal to advance legislation that aims to end the longest government shutdown in US history, which began on October 1, 2025. The shutdown, triggered by a political deadlock over healthcare spending, has affected millions of Americans. On Sunday night, senators passed a procedural vote to advance a bill that will be amended to fund the government until January 30, 2026. The agreement comes after months of disruptions, including the suspension of federal services and the furlough of employees. The shutdown, the first in nearly seven years, was a result of partisan divisions between Democrats and Republicans. The proposed bill will also prevent federal agencies from firing employees until January 30, a win for unions representing federal workers. The measure will now move to the House of Representatives for approval before being sent to President Donald Trump for final sign-off. item.title: London Police Operation Targets Phone Thieves and Other Criminals in Crime Crackdown
item.description: A recent crime crackdown in London's West End led to over 140 arrests, including phone thieves and a man involved in upskirting. The operation, known as Operation Baselife, was part of a broader effort by the Metropolitan Police to address anti-social behavior, shoplifting, phone theft, and violence against women ahead of the busy Christmas period. Among those arrested was a man who filmed women in a coffee shop, as well as two men attempting to steal mobile phones at an ice rink. Additionally, a stolen vehicle was intercepted with a stinger, and its occupants were arrested for car theft and drug possession. The police deployed more than 100 officers, and used advanced technology like facial recognition to assist in the operation. Superintendent Natasha Evans emphasized that this intelligence-led approach is yielding positive results, such as doubling the number of solved shoplifting cases. item.title: City executives plan £4m for Global Growth Market to back VC-backed companies
item.description: A group of executives in London's financial hub are pursuing a £4 million fundraising to launch the Global Growth Market (GGM), described as a “mini-Nasdaq” focused on venture capital-backed firms. Spearheaded by Jon Prideaux, former CEO of Boku, and Martin Graham, ex-AIM head, the initiative aims to revive public markets for growth companies by attracting capital from venture funds that predominantly invest in private businesses. The plan proposes eliminating fund management fees and carried interest, offering to provide half of eligible companies’ capital needs to incentivize participation. Prideaux emphasized that the public markets stopped working for growth companies years ago and stated that the GGM intends to reconnect companies and capital to the public markets with a more favorable deal for both sides. item.title: Air Traffic Controllers Resign Amid Prolonged Government Shutdown and Staffing Strain
item.description: Unpaid air traffic controllers in the United States are leaving their jobs at increasing rates as the government shutdown drags on, marking the longest in U.S. history. Officials report that the workforce is already short by hundreds of controllers, with about 730,000 federal employees affected by a pay halt since October 1. The resignations exacerbate existing bottlenecks at major airports, forcing agencies to implement reductions of air traffic in high-traffic markets. Controllers coping with burnout are calling in sick and expressing concerns about paying essential expenses, including gas and childcare. Some workers have even taken second jobs, despite warnings from officials to avoid compromising safety. Transportation Secretary and other leaders acknowledge the mounting fatigue and stress among staff who continue to report to duty for six days a week, long hours, and increasing fatigue. item.title: Brazil Sees Major Drop in Emissions Following Crackdown on Deforestation
item.description: Brazil has reported its largest drop in emissions since 2009, driven by the country's renewed efforts to combat illegal deforestation. Under President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, who returned to power in 2022, there has been a concerted effort to address the rising levels of forest clearing, which had been largely unchecked during the presidency of Jair Bolsonaro. Deforestation in the Amazon is at its lowest level in over a decade, a major factor in the significant reduction in emissions. A new report from the Climate Observatory shows that Brazilian emissions fell by 16.7% in the past year. The decline highlights the impact of federal enforcement against illegal activities by miners, loggers, and farmers who destroy forests for land expansion. While Lula aims to eliminate illegal deforestation by the end of the decade, the country still faces the challenge of widespread fires, which, despite the reductions in deforestation, continue to threaten forest preservation. item.description: Mali is currently facing a major humanitarian crisis due to a persistent fuel blockade that has lasted several weeks. Jihadist groups, particularly JNIM (affiliated with Al Qaeda), have targeted fuel-carrying trucks coming from neighboring countries, escalating by stealing vehicles and kidnapping drivers. This has resulted in a critical shortage of fuel throughout Mali, causing severe disruptions in transportation, electricity supply, and economic activity, especially in the central and southern regions and in the capital, Bamako. Only one out of ten gas stations in Bamako remained operational by late October, with long lines and people waiting overnight for fuel, as attacks continued despite military escorts. The jihadists justify their blockade as a reaction to government policies that limit fuel deliveries to villages cooperating with them, but have now expanded into a nationwide embargo in an attempt to undermine the military-led government, which came to power in 2021. item.description: On November 6, 2025, during an event in the Oval Office focused on drug-price cuts, President Donald Trump appeared to struggle with staying awake. For a period of about 20 minutes, Trump was seen repeatedly blinking and seemingly fighting to keep his eyes open while attending the meeting. This unusual display raised concerns and prompted further media coverage. The event, part of a broader initiative aimed at addressing healthcare costs, highlighted the challenges Trump faces while balancing his public duties. While the president’s apparent fatigue during the event captured attention, there was no official explanation provided for his behavior at that time. The footage, which was widely shared across social media platforms, sparked a mix of reactions, with some expressing concern for his well-being, while others speculated about the reasons behind his drowsiness. item.description: The article explores how modern digital infrastructure has facilitated an increase in methods and efficiency for authoritarian governments to exert control over populations. It provides examples of surveillance technologies, centralized data management, and legal frameworks that enable monitoring and censorship, discussing both historical context and recent policy shifts. The text emphasizes the role of global tech corporations working with state actors to build systems that prioritize control and compliance over privacy or civil liberty. Case studies from various countries highlight the interplay between domestic policy choices and international market pressures, underlining the complexity of digital authoritarianism beyond simple government decrees. item.title: South Korean Universities Reject Applicants Over Bullying Histories Despite Strong Academics
item.description: In a significant shift in South Korean university admissions, 45 students were rejected by major institutions, including Seoul National University, due to past involvement in bullying, even though they had excellent academic records. This change marks a move toward considering personal character alongside academic achievements in admissions decisions. The rejected students had applied through the regular admissions route, and although they had outstanding scores on the College Scholastic Ability Test (CSAT), their disciplinary histories related to bullying led to their disqualification. The new policy follows a 2023 scandal where public outrage over the leniency shown to an applicant with a bullying history pushed for stricter measures. item.title: Europe's Ambitious Mission to Explore Enceladus, Saturn's Moon
item.description: Europe is preparing to launch one of the most ambitious space missions in history: the exploration of Enceladus, one of Saturn's moons. Known for its geysers, which suggest the presence of an ocean beneath its icy surface, Enceladus could hold the key to understanding life beyond Earth. The mission, slated to launch between 2042 and 2046, will involve two Ariane 64 rockets. One will carry the propulsion stage into orbit, while the other will deliver the spacecraft. The mission will include both an orbiter and a lander, with the goal of studying Enceladus up close. The lander will descend to the moon's south pole to analyze geysers and the conditions necessary for life. Despite the challenges, such as the lack of plutonium-based power systems and the distant location of Saturn, the mission is a significant step for the European Space Agency (ESA) and could provide important insights into the potential for life on other planets. item.description: Israel is currently working on identifying the body of a deceased hostage who was recently returned from Gaza. The deceased individual’s identity is crucial for closure for the victim’s family and for Israeli authorities as they continue efforts to understand the full scope of the hostage situation. item.description: Ukrainian soldiers are facing an alarming increase in amputations as a result of the ongoing war. The high number of amputations is being attributed to the severity of battlefield injuries caused by artillery and landmines. Medical experts working on the frontlines have expressed concern over the strain this is putting on Ukraine’s healthcare system, which is already stretched thin by the constant influx of wounded soldiers. The country's doctors are being forced to make difficult decisions on the battlefield, as they try to save soldiers' lives while managing overwhelming numbers of casualties. item.description: The article critically examines the historical context and consequences of the so-called 'Green March', a controversial event that led to the occupation of Western Sahara by Morocco in 1975. The march, presented by Morocco as a peaceful, religiously driven demonstration, was supported by tens of thousands of Moroccan civilians. It was intended to force Spain to relinquish control of the territory, leading to a division of Western Sahara between Morocco and Mauritania. Despite the peaceful façade, the operation was heavily orchestrated by the Moroccan military, and its ultimate goal was the annexation of Western Sahara. The author argues that the true nature of the march was a betrayal of the Sahrawi people, who were left without their right to self-determination. item.description: A Palestinian prisoner, Muhammad Hussein Ghawadra, aged 63, died on Sunday in Megido/Janout prison in Israel, according to the Palestinian Prisoners and Ex-prisoners Committee. His death brings the toll of Palestinians who have died in custody to 81 since 1967. Detained since August of the previous year, he hailed from Jenin in the West Bank. One of his sons remains in administrative detention, while another was released in October under a ceasefire deal between Israel and Hamas. In the weeks surrounding his death, nearly two thousand Palestinian prisoners were released as part of the ceasefire agreed on October 10. item.description: Roman Novak, a Russian cryptocurrency investor and creator of the Fintopio program, and his wife, Anna, were found brutally murdered in the UAE, with their bodies dismembered and discarded in garbage bins. Novak, who had raised approximately $500 million in investments for Fintopio, had vanished with the funds, leaving employees unpaid and investors, including those from China and the Middle East, with heavy losses. Novak often claimed to be a close associate of Pavel Durov, the founder of Telegram, although Durov denied any connection. The couple was allegedly lured to a villa in Hatta under the pretense of meeting potential investors, where they were confronted by individuals demanding the keys to Novak’s crypto wallet. When the wallet was found empty, the assailants killed the couple and dismembered their bodies. item.description: Western capitals are facing a growing challenge from Chinese companies setting up shop in key commercial hubs, with brands like Huawei, TikTok, Nexperia, and DJI dominating the market. Shein, the Chinese fast-fashion giant, has now made its way to the heart of French retail, opening its first physical store in Paris. This marks a significant shift as traditional French stores, including the prestigious Galeries Lafayette, struggle with mounting debt. item.description: During a press conference with Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban, President Donald Trump, 79, struggled to answer a question about affordability and called on his press secretary, Karoline Leavitt, 28, to assist him. item.description: In a desperate attempt to bolster its ranks, Ukraine has reportedly recruited approximately two thousand Colombians to fight on the front lines as mercenaries. These recruits are primarily motivated by the financial compensation, with many lacking prior military experience. A few Spanish-speaking Ukrainian instructors are tasked with training them in combat tactics. The pay for these foreign recruits is just under 3,000 euros per month, and unlike Ukrainian soldiers, they can terminate their contracts at any time. item.description: Razan Al Najjar, a 21-year-old Palestinian paramedic, was tragically killed by an Israeli sniper on June 1, 2018, while aiding an injured protester during a demonstration. Known as the 'Angel of Mercy,' she was a symbol of hope for Palestinians and was revered for her tireless humanitarian work. Despite her clear identification as a medical worker, the Israeli military claimed she was a threat or used as a human shield, but a UN investigation concluded otherwise, affirming her murder was intentional. Her death, which occurred just before her engagement to her fiancé, drew international outrage and made her a martyr for the Palestinian cause. item.description: The Florentine diamond, a 137-carat yellow pear-shaped gem once linked to the Habsburg dynasty, has resurfaced after a hundred years. Descendants disclosed that the diamond was stored in a Canadian bank vault under Empress Zita's orders during World War II and had remained there all along, despite public belief in its disappearance. The reveal follows a broader controversy surrounding royal jewels that captured global attention, including a Louvre heist that brought renewed interest to missing artefacts. According to family accounts, after escaping Nazi persecution to Canada, the Habsburgs kept the Florentine secure with other jewellery, revealing its location only to Zita's sons and later to their own children for security until 100 years after Charles I’s death in 1922. Several relatives confirmed the story to major outlets, and the family now contemplates publicly exhibiting the diamond as a gesture of appreciation to Canada for sheltering the former monarch's kin. item.title: Retrasos en tratamientos innovadores de cáncer en Andalucía ponen en riesgo vidas
item.description: Diversos informes internos de la Junta de Andalucía han puesto de manifiesto importantes demoras en la administración de terapias avanzadas para pacientes con mieloma múltiple, un tipo de cáncer que afecta la médula ósea. item.title: Cayetano Rivera es captado conduciendo sin cinturón tras su reciente accidente de tráfico
item.description: Cayetano Rivera ha sido fotografiado nuevamente al volante, a pesar de las polémicas surgidas tras su reciente accidente de tráfico. El pasado 9 de noviembre, el torero sufrió un accidente con su furgoneta en las afueras de Sevilla, aunque salió ileso. Según su abogado, el accidente ocurrió debido a un despiste cuando buscaba el mando a distancia para acceder a su casa. La controversia aumentó cuando se filtró un informe de la policía en el que se mencionaba que Rivera se negó en varias ocasiones a someterse a una prueba de alcoholemia. En la última aparición del torero, fue captado sin cinturón de seguridad mientras conducía, lo que generó nuevas críticas. Aunque al darse cuenta de la presencia de las cámaras, se apresuró a ponerse el cinturón. Este comportamiento ha levantado aún más la polémica sobre su actitud al volante.

El dato ha llamado la atención porque los magrebíes representan únicamente el 1,7 % de los residentes en la comunidad —unas 37.800 personas de un total de más de dos millones—, mientras que los nacidos en España superan el 90 %. Desde octubre, la policía autonómica vasca ha comenzado a publicar estadísticas diferenciadas por nacionalidad y también por origen territorial dentro de España, separando entre vascos y ciudadanos del resto de comunidades autónomas. En lo que va de año, 1.817 de los detenidos eran vascos y 449 procedían de otras regiones. item.title: Trump regala su perfume al presidente sirio durante una visita histórica a la Casa Blanca
item.description: El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, protagonizó un llamativo episodio durante la visita oficial del presidente sirio Ahmed al-Sharaa a la Casa Blanca. Al-Sharaa respondió que solo una, a lo que Trump replicó, demostrando su habitual estilo poco diplomático. El acto fue filmado y difundido por redes sociales. item.title: El Congreso aprueba la Ley de Atención a la Clientela con nuevas medidas contra el spam telefónico y abusos al consumidor
item.description: El Congreso de los Diputados ha aprobado este jueves la nueva Ley de Atención a la Clientela con 179 votos a favor, 33 en contra y 138 abstenciones. La norma, impulsada por el Ministerio de Consumo, salió adelante con el apoyo de Junts y la abstención del Partido Popular. Su objetivo es establecer estándares básicos de calidad para garantizar una atención más justa y eficaz al consumidor, evitando abusos habituales en los servicios de atención y contratación. Entre las principales medidas destaca la prohibición de las llamadas comerciales no solicitadas o 'spam', que deberán identificarse con un prefijo específico. Las operadoras estarán obligadas a bloquear aquellas llamadas que no lo cumplan. Asimismo, cualquier contrato derivado de una de estas comunicaciones no consentidas será nulo. La ley también fija un tiempo máximo de espera de tres minutos en las llamadas de atención al cliente y un plazo de respuesta de quince días para reclamaciones. item.title: Colonos radicales en Cisjordania queman una mezquita mientras desafían a los mandos militares
item.description: La noticia describe un acto de violencia coordinada cometido por colonos encapuchados en Der Istiya, cerca de Nablus, que prendieron fuego a la mezquita local tras una jornada de extremismo violento. Este evento se enmarca en un contexto más amplio de tensiones en Cisjordania desde la escalada de la ofensiva en Gaza. En paralelo, se reportó un ataque a una empresa de productos lácteos palestina durante el mismo día, con daños significativos y cuatro sospechosos arrestados. Las autoridades militares israelíes condenaron la violencia y el general Avi Bluth calificó las acciones de inaceptables, aunque no se detallaron medidas concretas. Organizaciones internacionales y la ONU han señalado que la violencia de los colonos ha aumentado y que la impunidad persiste en muchos casos. En Washington, el secretario de Estado de Estados Unidos expresó preocupación por la inestabilidad en la región y su posible impacto en el alto el fuego en Gaza. El informe también señala que la anexión de Cisjorda

item.title: Detenida una policía municipal de Madrid por dañar el coche del periodista Nacho Abad
item.description: Una agente de la Policía Municipal de Madrid, identificada como Paola G. O., fue arrestada a finales de octubre por vandalizar el coche del periodista Nacho Abad. La mujer rayó el vehículo del periodista, un Tesla, en varias ocasiones y fotografió los daños con su teléfono móvil. El incidente ocurrió en un aparcamiento en Moncloa, donde la agente estacionó su coche junto al de Abad, lo reconoció, y, tras hacer fotos del coche del periodista, lo rayó por ambos lados con una llave. Tras ser detenida por la policía, la funcionaria fue puesta en libertad a la espera de juicio. Este suceso se enmarca en un contexto de creciente polarización política, como señaló Abad en su programa, donde lamentó la violencia y el acoso que está sufriendo. La investigación sigue en curso y la Policía Municipal no ha confirmado si se abrirá un expediente disciplinario a la agente implicada.

item.title: El proceso por el asesinato de Teófilo del Valle avanza con declaraciones telemáticas de Martín Villa y Aroca del Rey
item.description: La noticia informa sobre el avance de la investigación y el proceso judicial relacionado con Teófilo del Valle, la primera víctima de la violencia policial durante la Transición. La Coordinadora Estatal de Apoyo a la Querella Argentina (CEAQUA) y otros actores han destacado que este caso permitiría, por primera vez en España, aplicar la categoría de crímenes contra la humanidad a responsables de la dictadura, entre ellos un exministro y un agente de las fuerzas represivas. José Antonio del Valle, hermano de la víctima, y Manuel de Juan, guionista del documental La tres muertes de Teófilo del Valle, han explicado en rueda de prensa que José Antonio presentó en abril de 2024 una querella ante los juzgados de Elda con el respaldo de CEAQUA. Los hechos se remontan a febrero de 1976, cuando Teófilo fue asesinado durante la represión policial en Alacant, en un periodo de movilización de trabajadores del calzado demandando mejoras laborales. El Juzgado de Elda admitió a trámite la querella en

item.title: El 7,4 % de los jóvenes españoles presenta riesgo suicida elevado, según un informe de Unicef
item.description: Un informe elaborado por Unicef, Red.es, la Universidad de Santiago de Compostela y el Consejo General de Colegios Profesionales de Ingeniería Informática alerta sobre el preocupante aumento del riesgo suicida entre los jóvenes españoles. A partir de 100.000 encuestas a estudiantes de entre 10 y 20 años, el estudio revela que el 7,4 % de los adolescentes presenta un riesgo suicida elevado y el 6,5 % ha intentado quitarse la vida. Uno de cada cinco ha pensado en hacerlo y un 9 % incluso planificó cómo. El informe señala que las chicas duplican a los chicos en riesgo suicida (10,1 % frente al 4,3 %) y son el 74,3 % de las hospitalizadas por depresión. Los síntomas de ansiedad (13,7 %) y depresión (13,1 %) también son frecuentes, junto con manifestaciones de tristeza, desinterés o sentimientos de inutilidad. Además, la violencia entre hijos y padres está muy presente: en ocho de cada diez hogares se ha registrado algún episodio, desde discusiones y gritos hasta empujones. Las chicas tiend

item.title: Ayuso critica a Vox por su enfoque migratorio y defiende una inmigración vinculada al trabajo
item.description: La presidenta de la Comunidad de Madrid, Isabel Díaz Ayuso, ha cargado contra Vox durante el pleno de la Asamblea de Madrid por su propuesta de política migratoria. Ayuso defendió una inmigración “ordenada” y ligada al trabajo, subrayando que las fronteras deben mantenerse en orden y recordando que esas competencias no corresponden a la Comunidad de Madrid. Frente a las críticas de la portavoz de Vox, quien tildó la propuesta de “cosmopaleta” por favorecer que lleguen más personas, Ayuso enfatizó que las personas se desplazan hacia donde existen oportunidades y advirtió contra un “efecto expulsión”. Además, acusó a Vox de ofender a los hispanos y recalcó su objetivo de convertir Madrid en un lugar próspero con oportunidades libres para trabajar. El intercambio refleja las tensiones en la política española respecto a la inmigración y el papel de las comunidades autónomas frente a propuestas de partidos nacionalistas o extremistas.

item.title: Alemania prepara el regreso del servicio militar obligatorio tras acuerdo parlamentario
item.description: El Gobierno de Alemania ha alcanzado un acuerdo entre los principales partidos gobernantes, la CDU y el SPD, para establecer un mecanismo que permita pasar del servicio militar voluntario al obligatorio en caso de que el reclutamiento voluntario no sea suficiente para cubrir las necesidades de la Bundeswehr o ante una situación de crisis o conflicto. El ministro de Defensa, Boris Pistorius, ha adelantado que la activación del servicio obligatorio requerirá una ley y una votación parlamentaria, ya que el servicio militar obligatorio fue suspendido hace 14 años. El plan prevé aumentar el número de tropas activas hasta 260.000 y los reservistas hasta 200.000, aunque aún no se ha determinado la cifra exacta ni la capacidad de acogida del Ejército. El modelo sueco, basado en criterios de aptitud, es defendido por Pistorius, mientras que los conservadores prefieren un sistema aleatorio. Expertos militares consideran que el reclutamiento voluntario por sí solo no será suficiente y que la nuev

item.title: La Asociación de Fútbol de Irlanda pide la expulsión de Israel de las competiciones europeas
item.description: El 10 de noviembre de 2025, la Asociación de Fútbol de Irlanda (FAI) aprobó una resolución para solicitar a la UEFA la exclusión de Israel de las competiciones europeas. La propuesta, respaldada por varios clubes y asociaciones, señala la violencia de Israel en Gaza y la muerte de 344 futbolistas. Además, se denuncia la falta de políticas contra el racismo por parte de la Asociación de Fútbol de Israel (IFA). La moción también aborda la situación de los clubes israelíes que operan en territorios palestinos ocupados. La resolución llega en un momento de creciente incomodidad en el ámbito del fútbol europeo respecto a la implicación de Israel en el conflicto palestino. Aunque la UEFA aún no ha tomado una decisión final, las tensiones en torno a la participación de Israel en competiciones internacionales siguen aumentando.

item.title: Israel bloquea el acceso de UNICEF a materiales esenciales para vacunar a niños en Gaza
item.description: El Fondo de las Naciones Unidas para la Infancia (UNICEF) ha denunciado que las autoridades israelíes están bloqueando la entrada en la Franja de Gaza de jeringuillas y refrigeradores solares necesarios para conservar y administrar vacunas a miles de niños. Estos equipos, fundamentales para una nueva campaña de inmunización, son considerados por Israel como material de “doble uso”, lo que impide su entrada pese a su carácter claramente médico. La iniciativa busca recuperar la vacunación perdida durante los últimos dos años de conflicto, en los que el sistema sanitario ha sido devastado y más del 20% de los menores de tres años no han recibido las dosis básicas contra enfermedades como el sarampión, la polio o la difteria. UNICEF había previsto tres rondas de vacunación y la supervisión del estado nutricional de los menores, pero la falta de material básico amenaza con paralizar el proyecto. La situación humanitaria en Gaza sigue siendo crítica: la ONU denuncia que apenas entran un cent

item.title: Colonialismo israelí: ataque y quema de mezquita en Cisjordania
item.description: Este jueves, un grupo de colonos israelíes prendió fuego a la mezquita Al Hajja Hamida, ubicada entre las localidades de Deir Istiya y Kafr Haris, en el centro de Cisjordania. Aunque el incendio causó daños en el templo, la intervención de los vecinos evitó que el fuego se propagara, sin que se registraran heridos. Además de los daños materiales, los colonos dejaron mensajes racistas en las paredes de la mezquita, lo que refleja el creciente clima de violencia en la región. Este ataque se suma a una serie de acciones violentas por parte de colonos israelíes, que en octubre de 2025 protagonizaron más de 260 incidentes en Cisjordania, alcanzando una cifra récord. La tensión en la zona ha aumentado considerablemente tras el 7 de octubre de 2023, con más de mil palestinos muertos debido a la violencia, incluidos ataques de colonos y operaciones del Ejército israelí. Estos episodios se producen en un contexto de creciente incertidumbre política, tanto en el ámbito local como en las relacion

item.title: El Ayuntamiento de Madrid rechaza renovar el homenaje a Lucrecia Pérez en el aniversario de su asesinato racista
item.description: El alcalde de Madrid, José Luis Martínez-Almeida, ha decidido no respaldar este año el tradicional homenaje a Lucrecia Pérez, una mujer dominicana asesinada en 1992 en un crimen racista cometido por un guardia civil y tres jóvenes de extrema derecha. Su muerte supuso un punto de inflexión en la conciencia social española sobre el racismo y la xenofobia. Desde hace más de tres décadas, su memoria se recuerda cada 13 de noviembre, especialmente en el distrito de Moncloa-Aravaca, donde ocurrieron los hechos. Sin embargo, en 2025, el Ayuntamiento de Madrid, liderado por Almeida, ha optado por no apoyar la propuesta de Más Madrid para renovar el tributo institucional. El grupo liderado por Rita Maestre acusa al Partido Popular de ceder ante la presión de Vox y de blanquear los discursos racistas con fines electorales. Según Más Madrid, esta negativa demuestra una ‘falta de principios’ y una falta de respeto hacia la memoria de las víctimas del racismo. En años anteriores, el homenaje había

item.title: España se queda atrás en movilidad sostenible frente al resto de la UE según Puente
item.description: La entrevista con Óscar Puente, ministro de Transportes y Movilidad Sostenible, plantea que Europa está avanzando de forma irreversible hacia una movilidad más sostenible, salvo España, donde se observan retrocesos en la inversión de carriles bici en ciudades como Logroño, Valencia y Valladolid. Puente atribuye estos retrocesos a gobiernos de coalición en municipios con PP y Vox, y advierte que sin descarbonización la sociedad está en riesgo. Apuesta por una regulación que fomente la sostenibilidad, con énfasis en la movilidad, la asignación de fondos europeos y especialmente una fuerte inversión en transporte público. Señala que el proyecto de ley en el Congreso es clave para orientar estas medidas y que se esperan enmiendas del Partido Popular, que podrían mantener paradas de autobús y ajustar rutas y frecuencias. Puente defiende que la planificación debe ir acompañada de una reducción del uso irracional del coche en zonas de bajas emisiones, con medidas que no afecten desproporciona

item.title: España confina todas las aves de corral al aire libre para prevenir nuevos brotes de gripe aviar
item.description: El Ministerio de Agricultura, Pesca y Alimentación ha ordenado el confinamiento inmediato de todas las aves de corral criadas al aire libre en España. La medida, en vigor desde este jueves, afecta tanto a explotaciones industriales como ecológicas y a las de autoconsumo, y busca frenar el riesgo creciente de expansión de la gripe aviar en el país. La orden ministerial, publicada en el Boletín Oficial del Estado, amplía una restricción que hasta ahora solo afectaba a las zonas catalogadas de especial riesgo o vigilancia, abarcando ahora la totalidad del territorio español. El ministro Luis Planas ha señalado que la decisión responde al aumento de focos detectados en Europa y al desplazamiento de aves migratorias, cuya presencia en humedales españoles eleva la probabilidad de contagio. Desde julio se han registrado 139 brotes en granjas europeas y 14 en explotaciones españolas, principalmente en Castilla y León, además de 53 casos en aves silvestres y 5 en cautiverio. item.title: Aceleración capitalista: la acumulación mediante la muerte y sus implicaciones para la clase trabajadora
item.description: El artículo analiza la noción de aceleracionismo dentro del marco del capital, argumentando que las dinámicas actuales de acumulación ya no se limitan a despojar y exprimir, sino que buscan eliminar a la clase trabajadora para facilitar una circulación de capital sin obstáculos. Se retoma la idea de que la liberalización y la desregulación, junto con la automatización, la informatización y las redes, han intensificado la precariedad y desarraigo de las comunidades trabajadoras, desmantelando ritmos de vida tradicionales y aumentando la vulnerabilidad. Se destacan conceptos clave como la acumulación por desposesión y la crítica a las políticas neoliberales que han permitido la privatización de servicios públicos, la mercantilización de la vivienda y la expulsión de poblaciones, todo ello para acelerar los flujos de ganancia. El texto propone que la oposición anticapitalista no debe buscar una simple desaceleración, sino una pausa de emergencia para evitar una caída catastrófica del teji

item.title: Predicciones de emisiones para 2025 señalan incremento y retirada de la meta de 1,5°C
item.description: El Global Carbon Project, un consorcio internacional de 130 científicos, ha publicado una proyección mundial de emisiones de gases de efecto invernadero para 2025 que marca un camino más alto de lo deseable para cumplir el Acuerdo de París. Según el informe, las emisiones procedentes de combustibles fósiles aumentarían un 1,1% en 2025, alcanzando 38.100 millones de toneladas de CO2, lo que eleva la concentración atmosférica de CO2 a aproximadamente 425,7 partes por millón al cierre del año. Este comportamiento eleva el ritmo de crecimiento de las emisiones respecto a 2023 y supera la línea roja de los objetivos de 1,5°C. El estudio alerta que el presupuesto restante de carbono para mantener el calentamiento bajo 1,5°C podría agotarse antes de 2030 si las tendencias actuales continúan. Aunque se reconoce un progreso en la descarbonización de varios países, el informe indica que ese avance no es suficiente para contrarrestar la creciente demanda energética mundial.
